globalMetadataItem.description: A succinct description of what is in the dataset.
The "id" and "naming_authority" attributes are intended to provide a globally unique identification for each dataset. The id may be the file name without .nc suffix, which is designed to be unique.

The organization that provides the initial id (see above) for the dataset. The naming authority should be uniquely specified by this attribute. We recommend using reverse-DNS naming for the naming authority; URIs are also acceptable. Example: 'edu.ucar.unidata'.
Longer free-format text describing the dataset. This attribute should allow data discovery for a human reader. A paragraph of up to 100 words is appropriate.
The "ISO_Topic_Category" field is used to identify the keywords in the ISO 19115 - Geographic Information Metadata Topic Category Code List.
Comma-separated list of terms that will aid in discovery of the dataset.

Please use one of ‘GCMD Science Keywords’, 'SeaDataNet Parameter Discovery Vocabulary' or 'AGU Index Terms'. If multiple vocabularies are used, each keywords will need its corresponding vocabulary element. For DIF compliance, at least one GCMD keyword is required.
Data Assembly Center in charge of this data file. Use GCMD Data Centers list.
A statement describing the data distribution policy
Level of processing and quality control applied to data. Preferred values are listed in reference Table 3.
Name of the person responsible for metadata and formatting of the data file.
Email address of person responsible for metadata and formatting of the data file.
Describes the language used in the preparation, storage, and description of the data.
Describes the production status of the data set regarding its completeness.
Web address of the institution or of the data publisher.
The name of the platform used to acquire the data.
The scientific project that produced the data.

The method of production of the original data. If it was model-generated, source should name the model and its version, as specifically as could be useful. If it is observational, source should characterize it (e.g., "surface observation" or "radiosonde").

Provides an audit trail for modifications to the original data. Well-behaved generic netCDF filters will automatically append their name and the parameters with which they were invoked to the global history attribute of an input netCDF file. We recommend that each line begin with a timestamp indicating the date and time of day that the program was executed.
The citation to be used in publications using the dataset
Published or web-based references that describe the data or methods used to produce it.
Miscellaneous information about the data or methods used to produce it.
Allows the author to provide information that will enable the display of a sample image, movie or sound clip.
The "Related_URL" field specifies links to Internet sites that contain information related to the data
North/Tropical/South Atlantic/Pacific/Indian Ocean, Southern Ocean, Arctic Ocean. Geographical coverage. Try to compose of the following:
Latitude Resolution in units matching geospatial_lat_units.
Longitude Resolution in units matching geospatial_lon_units.
Indicates which direction is positive; "up" means that z represents height, while a value of "down" means that z represents pressure or depth. If not specified then "down" is assumed.
Vertical Resolution in units matching geospatial_vertical_units.
Interval between records: Use ISO 8601 (PnYnMnDTnHnMnS) e.g. PT5M for 5 minutes, PT1H for hourly, PT30S for 30 seconds.
A place to acknowledge various types of support for the project that produced this data.
A semi-colon-separated list of the names of any individuals or institutions that contributed to the creation of this data.
The email addresses of any individuals or institutions that contributed to the creation of this data, separated by semi-colons.
The roles of any individuals or institutions that contributed to the creation of this data, separated by semi-colons.
Update interval for the file, in ISO 8601 Interval format: PnYnMnDTnHnM where elements that are 0 may be omitted. Use "void" for data that are not updated on a schedule.
